results.title: West meets east
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Stedall, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this penultimate program Ronald Eyre visits the alternative communities of San Francisco, where westerners are searching for something to replace traditional religion, or the religion of science and progress, which seems to have replaced religion in the accepted sense in much of western society. The fundamental question he asks in this program is “Is God dead and did science kill him, and is science an adequate explanation of reality?” He talks to Theodore Roszak about the quest for meaning, and to noted physicists and philosophers, about the growing indadequacy of science to explain. Touching briefly on various manifestations of this search - biofeedback, sikhism, SAGE and the new physics, he concludes that the search itself is positive, even if the finding is sometimes shallow and negative.

results.title: A Question of balance
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Stedall, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this visit to Taiwan Ronald Eyre looks at Chinese religion and finds that the Chinese are Confucians, Taoists, Buddhists or can be all three at once. He explores the concept of yin and yan and the harmony which comes when good and evil are combined in balance. He takes his journey from a look at the local gods to the philosophy of the three accepted religions. The three main aims of the Chinese seem to be to live a long time, to have enough money and to have children, and it is from this that the importance of ancestors derive. He attends a village opera performance, a taoist funeral and explores a new temple which seems to include all three religions.

results.title: Zulu Zion
results.creator_credit: Mischa Scorer, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this visit to South Africa Ronald Eyre looks at the ways Christianity has evolved into an almost completely different religion, with an emphasis on dreams, purification, healing and the power of the holy spirit. Black Africans separated from the land search to replace these roots in God and the three different Christian sects which are explored here - the Zionists, the Lutherans and the Nazarites, all in their different ways have combined traditional African religion with Christianity. A fascinating look at how two different religions can merge and evolve into something quite unique and alive.

results.title: The Land of the disappearing Buddha
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this program Ronald Eyre looks at Japanese Buddhism, which is rather different to the Buddhism of Sri Lanka, which was explored in an earlier program. He visits a Zen Buddhist monastery and observes their austere and meditative rituals, which include martial arts and tea ceremonies. He then looks at Soka-ga-kai which is a new form of Buddhism catering to the masses, whose focus is the temple. He concludes by exploring the idea of the boddhisvata poised on the edge of eternity reaching back so that he can take others with him, rather than the Buddha himself who has passed beyond the reach of time.

results.title: The Way of the ancestors
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Feuerstein, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this program the producers have chosen the Turaja people of Sulawesi in Indonesia to represent cultures which still practice a ‘primal’ religion. Their particular form of religion emphasises the role of the ancestors which leads to extremely elaborate and lengthy funeral ceremonies with an emphasis on animal sacrifice. Ronald Eyre ponders on how these religions are coping with the modern world, in the form of christianity and ‘cultural tourism’, as well as trying to understand the religion itself. The film does contain scenes of animal sacrifice, although the viewer is warned of their approach.

results.title: The Chosen people
results.creator_credit: Brian Lewis, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this video Ronald Eyre explores the concept of “the chosen people” and the significance of the holocaust with Eli Wiesel, the leader of the Amadeus Quartet, a Jerusalem rabbi and a New York lawyer. He also discovers the Jewish love of words and argument, which stems from their need to constantly reinterpret the word of God, and their propensity to illustrate their arguments with humorous stories and jokes.

results.title: The Romanian solution
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Stedall, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Long Search”.
Even under the communist regime of 1977 it was estimated that 80% of the Romanian population were members of the Orthodox church. The Orthodox church lays claim to an uninterrupted 2000 years of unfragmented Christianity, a Christianity which gives great importance to the symbolic, particularly in the form of icons, which are windows into heaven. This is because the Orthodox believe that words do not suffice to convey the real meaning of what we feel. The program includes church ceremonies, and particularly the celebration of Easter.

results.title: There is no God but God
results.creator_credit: Mischa Scorer, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Long Search”.
It is estimated that one seventh of the world’s population is Moslem. In this program Ronald Eyre attempts to discover the essential core of Islam and of the Sufi sect in particular. This proves to be a difficult task, but in his search in Egypt he discovers that Islam means “making submission to Allah” and that therefore a Moslem is one who submits. The central message seems to be “there is no god but Allah and Mohammed is his messenger”, grounded on the rock of the Koran which sets out the five pillars of Islam. A fascinating but tantalising look at one of the world’s great religions.

results.title: Rome, Leeds and the desert
results.creator_credit: Mischa Scorer, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this program Ronald Eyre looks at three aspects of Catholicism; the triumphal pageant of Rome and the Pope, the beliefs of a British convert to Catholicism and her family in Leeds, and finally at the Little Brothers of Jesus who live in small groups in the community, except for the year they spend alone in the desert, and the time they spend training in Spain.

results.title: Footprint of the Buddha
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this episode Ronald Eyre visits a buddhist monastery in Sri Lanka to discover the meaning of buddhism. He finds that buddhism has no god; buddhists regard gods as useful but not crucial. The three basic principles of buddhism are to shun all evils, to do good, and to achieve purification of the mind. The individual can expect no external help, but must follow the noble eight-fold path to nirvana, using meditation to penetrate appearances and show the world as it is. The program includes the initiation of a young boy as a monk.
